repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
This is the first step in adding Pure Python code versions to all Cython documentation!

<s>Note, since the current tests for `.py` files do not add `cython` to namespace</s>, some tests are <s>expected</s> to fail due to the convention not to use `import cython` in most pure python files.

To be able to try this, you will need to install doc-requirements.txt (it has been updated).

Lots of process details and standardization are found here: #4187 

Small preview:
![Small preview](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52697657/121789417-7de0e100-cbde-11eb-84b7-8f5ec38f75c6.gif)

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
        to define some local C variables.
```

Also, the text that changes with the code tab is a good idea, but I wonder if it should be present as "part of" the tab.

comment_data.body: I haven't tried it but does `p: cython.int[1000] = [0] * 1000` work? I know if potentially initializes memory unnecessarily, but is saves the `if not cython.compiled`

+

comment_data.body:
> Couldn't you use linenos to not show the `import cython` that would make tests pass?
> 
> Edit: or `linenos-start`

Yes, we can, and I have already said this in the issue. The fact is that then all the other lines will be displaced, and it will be very inconvenient to edit them.
Look [here](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4187#issuecomment-859973066)

comment_data.body:
I really don't like the `_pure` suffix. We should avoid it if possible and use balanced names instead (where they make sense).
```suggestion
.. tabs::
    .. group-tab:: Cython

        .. figure:: htmlreport_pyx.png
            :scale: 90 %

    .. group-tab:: Pure Python

        .. figure:: htmlreport_py.png
            :scale: 90 %
```

comment_data.body:
It just seems wrong to me to have these under a different name than `setup.py` and to have them in files at all, where they expose a higher risk of not matching the text. It's too easy to rename one of the other files and forget to adapt this one.

The fact that this has been done before does not mean that it was previously a good decision.

comment_data.body:
> It's too easy to rename one of the other files and forget to adapt this one.

I cannot disagree. Putting this in separate files allows you to test them, but it probably makes very little sense, even more so compared to the possibility of forgetting to update them.
In general, I think I will agree, and in the near future I will add them as text.

comment_data.body:
I think a comment is needed here on why it's needed *or*

Like the conversation above suggests, I think you should do `p: cython.int[1000] = [0] * 1000` because it is in-fact the same as what Cython does (initialize a 1000 item long array).

My preference is the latter, but at least add a comment as the former suggests.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
        When we run this from Python we have to initialize the list,
        which is easiest done filling it with 0s (as seen on lines 8-9).
        When we compile this with Cython on the other hand, the array
        will be a 1000 items long with random data from previous allocations
        that we will overwrite.
```

comment_data.body:
> When we compile this with Cython on the other hand, the array
> will be a 1000 items long with random data from previous allocations
> that we will overwrite.

random -> arbitrary. The data is not random, that's a common misperception that we should not spread here.

```suggestion
        When we run this code from Python, we have to initialize the items in the array.
        This is most easily done by filling it with zeros (as seen on line 8-9).
        When we compile this with Cython, on the other hand, the array will
        behave as in C.  It is allocated on the function call stack with a fixed
        length of 1000 items that contain arbitrary data from the last time that
        memory was used.  We will then overwrite those items in our calculation.
```

+    n: cint = 2

+        n += 1
+
+    # Vectors are automatically converted to Python

comment_data.body:
> this already discussed in the explanation of the code

What is the first thing that you look at when skipping through this kind of documentation? Probably the example code. Only then would you scan the surrounding text for explanations if you feel like you need them. If the code is clear, or at least the explanation is right in the code, you don't need to search for it in the text.

People rarely read documentation from top to bottom. Some do, but we should cater for as many as we can.

comment_data.body:
> Perhaps the following is better then?

This improves your suggestion a little more: "C++ objects are automatically converted to Python objects, so the vector will be converted to a Python list."

But then again, more words explain the same thing.

Also, I don't really like the fact that we are only talking about C++ objects. It seems to me that this introduces ambiguity in understanding. Some might understand it like this: Only C++ objects are converted, and the rest, like C objects, do not.

What do you think about it @scoder?

+# distutils: language=c++
+
+import cython
+from cython.cimports.libcpp.vector import vector
+
+def primes(nb_primes: cython.uint):
+    i: cython.int
+    p: vector[cython.int]
+    p.reserve(nb_primes)  # allocate memory for 'nb_primes' elements.
+
+    n: cint = 2
+    while p.size() < nb_primes:  # size() for vectors is similar to len()
+        for i in p:
+            if n % i == 0:
+                break
+        else:
+            p.push_back(n)  # push_back is similar to append()
+        n += 1
+
+    # Vectors are automatically converted to Python
+    # lists when converted to Python objects.
